Posts.Content: thisisme wrote: Met with surgeon yesterday and will have L sided mastectomy.  She says I have 5% chance of recurrence onthe L side and 15% chance of recurrence on R side(no existing cancer there).  She did say that the L side was the life-threatening side- ie the one that would kill me.   Stupid me, did not ask for clarification.  If all the prognostic information says that I have about a 65-82% 5 year prognosis (probably Stage IIb or IIIa) , then what is the 5% about?   Would that not give me a 95% survival rate?  Could it be a 5% risk each year and be cumulative? Also chemo doctor says have 40-50% chance of "relapse".  Huh? Anyway, real question I should have asked is- what is the risk reduction of the 15% risk on non-cancerous side if I have mastectomy? Because she said that that side is not the life threatening side (is that because they would catch earlier? or ???) my guess is she would not support its removal and that is why she did not bring up that option.  Does anyone know the answers to these questions?  Especially the risk reduction due to prophy mastectomy?  Also, when do they usually like to do it? With the inital mast or after?  "Dont cry because it is over, Smile because it happened" Dr Seuss Surgery 3/8/2009 Mastectomy: Left Hormonal Therapy 5/31/2009 Hormonal Therapy 6/30/2011 Arimidex (anastrozole) Surgery 9/4/2011 Prophylactic ovary removal Chemotherapy 12/31/2011 Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 4/7/2014 Aromasin (exemestane) Targeted Therapy 4/7/2014 Afinitor (everolimus) Chemotherapy 5/31/2015 Halaven (eribulin) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2009 10:21AM thisisme wrote: Thanks everyone... Bugs, how did they find out if you were in permanent menopause?  Was it a blood test or did they just wait for a period? How long after chemo did you go through this?
Posts.Title: Ovaries and all that stuff..... thisisme nobleanna007

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2009 06:46AM - edited Apr 14, 2009 06:47AM by thisisme Lots to consider!  I still have 3 more chemos so have some time to think about it, but it sounds like lots of different routes are taken.  RIght now, i lean towards the ooph.  There were 4 weeks between the end of my first set of chemo and surgery and I got my period just after the surgery (just to add insult to injury).  I wonder if I should have been offered a Lupron shot in that time to prevent it? Gotta add that to the items for discussion with the onc. KerryMac- you are so close to finshing this stuff... go for it. I was looking at your stats and I am so close to you. I was Dx in 11/08, am 43, 6cm+, grade 2 and 6/10, er+, pr- (or slightly positive) and her2-.  and live very near you.  We should hook up at Sunnybrook after one of my chemos/your rad in next few weeks.
Posts.Title: Ovaries and all that stuff..... thisisme nobleanna007

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2009 12:32PM thisisme wrote: Hey fighting...... Take a breath, sister... Just look at what you have gone thru in the last 9 months, twins, chemo, rads, bmx, ooph, and still 3 other young kids.... If I had to guess, I would say that you are about to crash.  Your body probably doesn't even remember normal..... Even without bc, and with only 2 other kids, I was exhausted for 2 years following birth of #3. If I had to add 2 other kids in there and bc treatment, I would be flat out in bed..... I think you may have been running so hard in the last 9 months, that you have hit the wall.  Now, the wall might crumble around you, or you might be able to keep it up, but it will certainly be weakened.  Go take it easy.  I wouldn't expect your energy level to return for another 2 or 3 years.... about the same time that diapers are banished!

Are you getting your biopsy Nov 18 too?  We can do it. We can get through this and we can deal with whatever is given to us

Posts.Title: Cyberknife for liver mets? Rach958 thisisme

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2015 01:18PM thisisme wrote: I just had the second dose of my second cycle. The second cycle has certainly been easier than the first one. Maybe a bit tired and achy but, so far, so good. The hair is another story. There was so much hair in the shower last week that it looked like a guinea pig in there with me. The hair loss started about 5 days after the second dose of the first cycle. I am hoping it is slowing down a little bit now as I still have quite a lot, but rather thin around the part and hair line. I went to a wig shop, and she had little wigs that just sort of sat on the top of your head to cover hair thinning. It was good, as it mixed in easily with your own hair and looked quite natural. I hope everyone is feeling well, keeping their WBC up, and energy going.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2009 01:02PM thisisme wrote: With all the crap that we go through, all the fretting and worrying, all the "sneak peeks" at death, it was so refreshing to read about a pregnancy.  I am sorry that you have the indigestion and other preggo problems, but enjoy them as much as you can as it so sad when you realize it is the last one. Please keep updating us with preggo stuff.  Baby kicking well?  Have you washed his little teeny tiny clothes yet?  Does it smell like "baby"?  Can you believe how tiny the socks are? Here are some good preggo vibes.... and screw the bc.

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2009 04:19AM thisisme wrote: A canadian Sunnybrook patient and doing T-FEC, too.  A bit differently, though.  I am on a trial for LABC so have done rads with weekly low dose Taxotere,then surgery (March 4) and then will do more Taxotere to get me to the full dose followed by FEC.  Was anyone warned that FEC or AC can cause fatal leukemia?  I was told about 0.3% chance and it is freaking me out.
Posts.Title: Starting FEC-T tomorrow.... KerryMac pip57

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2015 10:05PM thisisme wrote: Hi ladies, I just wanted to check-in. I just had my 2nd dose of the first cycle. The first dose made me very very tired and I slept for 2 days. I also had a small flu going into it, so it might have just been that. I am hoping this dose doesn't do the same. So far I would say that I have low energy or am just being lazy as I havent done much today. No nausea, thought I saw more hair in the tub after a shower but then when we start looking for problems, we usually find them.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2015 05:18PM thisisme wrote: Maureen, I felt the same way after 1st dose. Like the flu. It got a bit better each day, for about 3-4 days. The second dose was better, just felt tired and unmotivated to get off the couch. The break has been really good, feel great. Going into my 3rd dose on Friday so hoping it is an easy one. Lost lots of hair in the shower last week so I guess the thinning is happening. Immediately called a photographer friend and she took a bunch of portrait shots so that I have those with hair! I am hoping I can hold on to most of it.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: May 17, 2015 07:09AM thisisme wrote: Any more room on the Halaven bus? I start it in 2 weeks. About 3 months ago, my scan showed some small liver mets had returned while on A/A and the scan at beginning of the month showed that they had grown a bit more so MO suggesting Halaven. I have a fun community gala coming up, so I asked to delay starting until early June. i am getting used to the idea of IV chemos, though it has felt like the "beginning of the end". The biggest bummer for me is that it ties me to the cancer agency and impacts my ability to travel. I had a friend with renal failure and he was able to travel by booking dialysis time at the city he was visiting. we should be able to do that, too. Thanks to al the great information on this board, I am feeling ok about starting the next phase in the journey......
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: thisisme wrote: I am 42, had sort of lumpy feeling in left breast, sometimes sore so eventually went to doc.  Doc not worried, unable to find a "lump" just general lumpiness in the area.  Waited 2 months for mam and US... got called back with this radiology report: Glandular tissue occupies 25% of breast  bilaterally Extensive pleomorphic calcifications involving the entire upper outer quadrant of left breast. Asymmetric density 1-2:00, left breast, 3 cm from nipple.  This corresponds to a large vague hypoechoic area on ultrasound 4.1 x 2 cm with distal shadowing.  Its margins are poorly delineated. Mamogram and Ultrasound otherwise unremarkable BiRADS 5 lesion upper outer quadrant left breast in keeping with extensive intraductal carcinoma.  Biposy required.  Taking 4 weeks to get biopsy! still have 10 more days to wait.  Clearly i am near collapse with worry.  Is it good news that it did not say spiculated margins or is everything else so bad, that it doesnt matter?  I have looked up everything on the web about each of these findings, and i think my only hope is for adenosis.  From what i have read, it can have all of the findings in my report.  If it is malignant, then i just hope i can be as strong as the other women here. Would like to hear others comments on the report, the good, the bad and the ugly. BTW, for first time in my life, I question the Canadian health care system.  Anyone else been through Sunnybrook for this? Posts.Title: Mam, US result and Rant about waiting thisisme Beesie

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2008 07:39PM thisisme wrote: Thanks for the moments of hope.  I go between *knowing* that all is well, to *knowing* I have mets.  Although my family doc is very worried for me ( I get the feeling she spoke the radiolgist that did my first mamo and was told it was very serious) she has not been successful in moving me up the wait list.  Sunnybrook has my films, too and the appt was booked after they got my films so maybe, maybe, maybe the rad there saw them and was not too worried by them?? I dont know if it is best to plan for the worst or hope for the best.  I cant do both at the same time.... I told my boss the other day that I had a very bad mamo and we should develop a contigency plan at work in case i need to be off.  Maybe a little premature, but it reduced my stress.  I am a consultant I have been bidding and getting lots of work, so I need to make sure that someone can pick up my pieces easily if I need to be off. Have not discussed with anyone else except husband. Thanks all for encouragement/advice and your caring.
Posts.Title: Mam, US result and Rant about waiting thisisme Beesie

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2014 06:24PM thisisme wrote: Lisa, if I can weigh in here.... My experience is to not worry about what treatment comes next.  You might not need to try anything new for a long time and I think that several things come into play when choosing the next step... like how long before progression, where the progression is, how aggressive you and the doc want to be, ect. Just focus on the treatment now, and deal with the next treatment when you need to.  Oh, and I was told the same thing about the cardiac effects. I dont know why it is called "restaging",it is really just evaluation of treatment.  Good Luck, one day at a time.

Posts.Title: Starting Chemo April 2009 tulipbebe MissouriCatLady

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2011 06:06PM thisisme wrote: Chickadee: you are right I meant Stage IV, not Stage V which I assume is the Stage in which you are undergrouind.  I cant edit the posting title so put it down to being in shock from the diagnosis.  Can not blame it on chemo brain as not on chemo.  Seems the first treatment option will be to remove my ovaries next week and then start on an AI, switching from Tamox..  I expect that to be an easy first step but who knows for how long..... Coolbreeze: I think you are right regarding the kids support.  Their dad has already said pretty much that he will be bringing kids back  to Toronto when I die.  So my plan for kids to be near family, etc wont come through when I am gone.  And kids will be disrupted again....I hate to make any decision based on his plans, but I have to make it in their best interest. Thanks for your thoughts. I know that no one can make this decision for me, but it is helpful to hear from those that are living with this for awhile to understand how it might impact me. Jacqui

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2009 05:53PM thisisme wrote: Thanks all!  My hair is still getting curlier each day.  How long do these chemo curls last?
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2009 07:54AM thisisme wrote: Marie, I never lost ALL my hair, I did buzz it down to about.25 inch when it began to fall out but left the wisps around my hairline so I would have some hair under my hat.  Those never completely fell out, although they did get very sparse.  Anyway, don't forget that you lost your hair around 3 weeks after first chemo, so don't expect your hair to grow back during the first 3 weeks pfc.  Then consider that it takes a bit for it grow long enough to push through your scalp.  So don't even expect to see anything to at least 6-7weeks pfc.  my pix are post shave which was 3 weeks pfc.Which means that the second pix is actually 7-8 weeks pfc.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: thisisme wrote: So I have just been diagnosed with mets and am not quite sure what is in store for me.  I need your advice on what you have been through and what it has been like so that I can make some plans.   I am a single mom of 3 boys. I used to live in Toronto where me the boys had our friends and activities all set up and other than a bad marriage were relatively happy. Then last year I moved the 4 of us to Vancouver, across the country. I did this for 2 reasons. 1) to escape the marriage and that seemed the best way at the time and 2) to be closer to my 2 sisters in case of a Stage IV diagnosis.... which has now happened.  I didnt want to die alone.  So I have been in Vancouver for a year and my kids hate, hate,hate it.  They have no friends, I also have found the last year really lonely as all my friends are in Toronto and I have not made a single Vancouver friend.  Who has time between work and trying to keep the 3 boys entertained so they dont cry about living in Vancouver.  .I am totally stressed and, to be honest, my family has been of limited help.  They have known how stressful it has been to be here on my own with the 3 boys and they have not offered to help.  Not even to take kids for a few hours so I can get haircut or do groceries.  Maybe I looked like I was coping too well! Although I did point blank ask them if they could consider helping me out once in a while.  Anyway, they are busy with their own families and friends. Anyway, since the mets Dx 1 month ago, they have been coming to doc appts with me and helping me make some decision,etc.  But still not helpful with the kids. I now have an opportunity to return to Toronto.  In Toronto I would have friends that would help with the kids, ie take them for the weekend, have them over for playdates, pick up from school etc, but no one to look after me, in the way that family does (ie holding my hair back as I puke, sitting with me after having a mastectomy, holding my hand at onc appts, etc  as they did when first diagnosed).But I would have friends to go to dinner with our out to the movies, etc.    Here is where I need your help.  I know that  no one can predict this stuff, but how hard has treatment been for you?  Could you have managed with just limited help around the house and to look after you?  I pretty much made it through the chemo at first Dx on my own, with my husband ignoring me but totally looking after the kids.  Could this journey be much worse than those first chemos?  I can afford to get some temp help in during the tough times but not all the time full time.  How would you have coped if you were doing this on your own? I really need to make the Vancouver/Toronto decision by December.  I would appreciate any thoughts on the limited benefits of family looking after you vs, friends for enjoyment!  Maybe other single moms can comment??? Thanks all for your wisdom as we take this journey..... Jacqui (edited title to make it "Stage IV") "Dont cry because it is over, Smile because it happened" Dr Seuss Surgery 3/8/2009 Mastectomy: Left Hormonal Therapy 5/31/2009 Hormonal Therapy 6/30/2011 Arimidex (anastrozole) Surgery 9/4/2011 Prophylactic ovary removal Chemotherapy 12/31/2011 Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 4/7/2014 Aromasin (exemestane) Targeted Therapy 4/7/2014 Afinitor (everolimus) Chemotherapy 5/31/2015 Halaven (eribulin) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2011 02:36AM thisisme wrote: Thanks all, some really good points. It is really helpful to hear how others have done this alone or with kids or in whatever situation.   And as has been said, I know in my heart what to do.  I also have to make sure that I plan for living, not dieing. Wow, Lena, you are a planner extra-ordinaire!  While reading your post I could not help but wonder what a man in our situation would do? Would he spend his last "healthy" day cleaning the house and grocery shopping or programming the TV to tape his favourite shows?  Would he be grocery shopping or off to the baseball game?  Just wondering! Before I posted, I had forgotten that I have the best support network around.... that is all of you on BCO.  No one else can really 'get it' like you can.  You have to live it to understand it. Cheers, Jacqui

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2009 08:42AM thisisme wrote: For some reason, I decided to shave my head 3 weeks pfc.  I liked being bald.  My 10 year old was mortified, my 5 year old thought it was cool and could I show all his friends and my 3 year old was oblivious.  I hated my wig and wore it for only 20 min.  I wore hats.  At 8 weeks post shave, i was going topless.  i never really lost all my eyebrows or lashes, but they did get shorter and sparser.  I used to have long thick lashes and now they are just average.  My hair came back greyer, softer and curlier.  I get frequent compliments on it.  Now at 4 months post shave, I am getting close to needing a trim just to give it more style.  Here I am at shave day, 3 weeks post shave, 4 weeks shave, and 3 months post shave " mce_src="" alt="shave day" border="" hspace="" vspace="" width="" height="" align="left" />" mce_src="" alt="3 weeks post shave" border="" hspace="" vspace="" width="" height="" align="right" /> " " mce_src="" alt="3 months post shave" border="" hspace="" vspace="" width="" height="" align="" />mce_src="" alt="4 weeks post shave" border="" hspace="" vspace="" width="" height="" align="left" />

I have been on a trial so have had a non-conventional treatment path.  I started with Taxotere at 1/4 strength and last one I had 2.5 weeks ago was full strength.  I had a bit of hair thinning during the 1/4 strength but now it is coming out in chunks.

I rocked it around the kitchen for a bit, kids joined in but mostly looked horrified at me and had a laugh. got me out of the funk.   that and also making a daily choice to be busy living and not busy dieing. this is my only cancer support group. I dont need to spend any more time talking about this sh*t.

Posts.Title: Memorial Sloan Kettering Study everyminute karen1956

Posts.Content: thisisme wrote: I month ago I had a bad mammo and u/s.  (details posted elsewhere).  Yesterday I had a core needle biopsy and while there they found a 'plump; node so the did a FNA of that, too.  Had lots of trouble getting the node as it kept slipping away.  For you Toronto based women, I had it at Sunnybrook and the tech was the saving grace.  She was awesome and if I ever have to return, I will personally wait until she can attend to me.  She explained everything and showed me what she saw and told me just what I needed to hear.  i will be sending her a thank you card.  (am I allowed to post her first name?) Anyway, went straight to my GPs office and asked for some Ativan.  I just felt that after waiting 2 months for the mammo and then 4 weeks for the biopsy, I could not hold it together any longer.  Plus now wait 1 week for result, which must be cancer from the look of those films.  Oh, after the biopsy I walked through the cancer centre and thought, okay, i can do this.  I watched 2 young women checking in for radiation and they were laughing, It was almost like they were buying tickets to a movie they were going to see.  When I saw them,I felt reassured that this can be dealt with and it can have positive moments. This morning I just felt overwhelmed and slipped one of those little Ativan guys under my tongue and it has been amazing.  I have been able to think about this and even talk about it without going into panic mode, I have felt calm for the first time in months and am feeling like I can take whatever is given to me.  Please, if you feel like I did... almost shaking with panic and spontaneous crying without warning, etc then please do ask for help.  You will be able to focus and make better decisions. Thanks for all the support I have had here.  I have a question.  What is a SNB? If they biopsied a node yesterday, is that a SNB?  Oh, one more piece of advice- take some extra strenght tylenol with you to have after the biopsy as it hurts a bit once freezing comes off.  But do not take any aspirin based products! Causes bleeding. Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2009 08:07PM thisisme wrote: I had the test and it showed that I was an intermediate.  My onc was not too excited by it.  What she really focused on was the fact that I had hot flashes from the tamoxifen.  She thought that was the most reliable test of my tamoxifen uptake.  I am not convinced as I am also on Zoladex but being an intermediate is not bad as long as i dont take other CYP2D6 drugs.  I might get switched to an AI once ovaries are out and I recover from recon.  I get the impression that she really wants me on tamox first before an AI.

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2014 10:06PM thisisme wrote: Sorry, I dont know this drug, however, if it is meant to be given just under the skin, then the nurses will use a small short needle and use a different injection technique to get it to the right place. If it was given into muscle, it would be given with a long needle (at least 1.5 inches) and you would feel it more.Injections meant to be given into muscles are usually given in the arm or butt or thigh. those into fat are given into stomach, back of arm, etc. with a small needle and at an angle. Even if you are thin, it will go into fat.

Posts.Title: Palbociclib (Ibrance): Who would get this? RosesToeses Moderators

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2014 08:43AM thisisme wrote: I used it the first time around. I couldnt get the nausea under control and this was a miracle answer for me.  I only needed a few puffs to take away the nausea. I was able to almost eliminate all my nausea meds.  Even just a few puffs did make me a bit high which I have never enjoyed but so worth it to get rid of that sick feeling.  I will definitely use it again when I go on stronger chemo that causes nausea.  We have legal medical marijuana here in B.C. and feel more comfortable as I know that it has not been laced with anything else.  The dispensaries can suggest which type will be most helpful with your problem (nausea, pain, appetite etc).  good luck.
